questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the cavernous part of the internal carotid artery?
questions.solution:
The pterygoid branch is not a branch of the cavernous part of the internal carotid artery. It is a branch of the petrous part.

Angiography reveals the characteristic finding of carotid siphon showing multiple bends and producing an S-shaped shadow. The image given below is a magnetic resonance angiogram showing the segments of internal carotid artery.

Related Pearl: Internal carotid artery branches

Part
Course
 Branches
Cervical part
Originates from the bifurcation of the common carotid artery. It has a dilation at the lower end which is known as carotid sinus. It ascends in front of the transverse process of the upper three cervical vertebrae.
 No branches given
Petrous part
Passes through the carotid canal in the petrous part of the temporal bone
  • Caroticotympanic branch
  • Artery to the pterygoid canal
Cavernous part
Runs in the cavernous sinus
  • Branch to the trigeminal ganglion
  • Meningeal branch
  • Branch to the cavernous sinus
  • Hypophyseal branches
Cerebral part/ Supracavernal part
Enters subarachnoid space by piercing arachnoid mater and divides into the anterior and middle cerebral arteries.
  • Ophthalmic artery
  • Anterior choroidal artery
  • Posterior communicating artery

The petrous, cavernous and intracranial parts of the internal carotid artery are called the carotid siphon because of its sigmoid course.

questions.text: A 73-year-old hypertensive patient was rushed to the casualty following a transient ischemic attack. Angiography revealed stenosis of the internal carotid artery. Which part of this artery does not give any branch?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transient ischemic attack due to internal carotid artery stenosis. The cervical part of the internal carotid artery does not give off any branches.

The image given below shows the internal carotid artery.

questions.text: A man presented with an excruciating headache and double vision. On examination, the following findings were observed. MRI revealed an aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery. The affected artery is a branch of ______.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of ptosis, down and out eyes and dilated pupils is suggestive of an oculomotor nerve palsy secondary to a posterior communicating artery aneurysm. The posterior communicating artery is a branch of the cerebral part of the internal carotid artery. 

The image given below shows the posterior communicating arteries in the circle of Willis.

questions.text: Which of the following is an unpaired vessel in the central nervous system?
questions.solution:
The basilar artery and the anterior spinal artery are unpaired arteries in the central nervous system.

The basilar artery is a single artery formed by the union of two vertebral arteries.

The anterior spinal artery is a single artery formed from a branch from each vertebral artery near its termination.

questions.text: The labyrinthine artery most commonly arises from which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
The labyrinthine artery is most commonly a branch of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA). It can also be a direct branch of the basilar artery at times.

The basilar artery is formed by the union of two vertebral arteries. At the upper border of the pons, it divides into two posterior cerebral arteries.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the casualty with a severe headache, fever, and vomiting for the past 8 hours. His CT scan and CSF appearance are shown below. The affected vessels do not get a contribution from:
questions.solution:
These patient's clinical features as well as the CT scan showing blood in the cistern and the xanthochromatic CSF appearance are suggestive of subarachnoid haemorrhage. The affected vessels i.e. the circle of Willis do not get a contribution from the middle cerebral artery.

The circle of Willis is located in the interpeduncular fossa at the base of the brain. It is an anastomosis between the internal carotid arteries and vertebral arteries. It allows the blood entering from either artery to be distributed to both the cerebral hemispheres.

The arteries forming the circle of Willis are:

  • Anterior communicating artery
  • Anterior cerebral arteries
  • Internal carotid arteries
  • Posterior communicating arteries
  • Posterior cerebral arteries
  • Basilar artery

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: A man presented with hemiparesis involving the entire left side of the body except for the left leg. MRI revealed a stroke involving the right primary motor cortex. Which vessel is likely to be thrombosed?
questions.solution:
The middle cerebral artery supplies the entire motor area except for the leg area. Thus, a lesion in the middle cerebral artery causes contralateral hemiparesis, sparing the leg area.

Anterior cerebral artery:
  • It is the smaller terminal branch of the internal carotid artery.
  • It runs in the sagittal fissure and anastomoses with the posterior cerebral artery.
  • It supplies the medial surface of the cerebral cortex and parts of lentiform, caudate nuclei and the internal capsule.
Middle cerebral artery:
  • It is the larger terminal branch of the internal carotid artery.
  • It runs in the lateral sulcus.
  • It supplies the entire lateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere except for a narrow strip (supplied by the anterior cerebral artery) and the occipital pole and the inferolateral surface (supplied by the posterior cerebral artery).
Posterior cerebral artery:
  • It is the terminal branch of the basilar artery.
  • It supplies the occipital lobe, inferolateral and medial surfaces of the temporal lobe, and parts of the brainstem.

questions.text: A woman presents with homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing as shown below. She complains of an inability to distinguish objects when they are placed in front of her. But when moved, she can observe and distinguish them. This is due to the occlusion of which artery?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with visual field defects and Riddoch phenomenon is suggestive of occipital lobe lesion occurring due to the occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery. 

The visual cortex is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery. Its occlusion is commonly seen in head injury and may be associated with visual hallucinations, denial of blindness (Anton syndrome), and the Riddoch phenomenon (only moving visual targets are perceived). These lesions generally spare the central vision/macular vision.

The anatomical reason for this sparing is attributed to the uniqueness in the blood supply. The part of the occipital lobe representing the peripheral field vision is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery. Whereas, the area at the tip of the calcarine cortex representing the central macular vision, is supplied by a branch of the middle cerebral artery.

questions.text: The chief artery of the superolateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere is:
questions.solution:
The chief artery of the superolateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere is the middle cerebral artery. 

Both the anterior and middle cerebral artery supply the superolateral surface of the brain but anterior cerebral artery supplies only a narrow strip at the upper superolateral surface rest is supplied by the middle cerebral artery. Therefore, the chief artery is the middle cerebral artery.

The chief artery of the medial surface of the brain is an anterior cerebral artery.

The chief artery of the inferior surface of the brain is the posterior cerebral artery.

Lateral cerebral artery is not an artery.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man was diagnosed with stroke. A thrombus in the marked vessel will affect all of the following structures except:
questions.solution:
The marked vessel is posterior cerebral artery. It does not supply the pons, hence a thrombus in this artery will not affect the pons.

 The branches of the posterior cerebral artery are:

  • Cortical branches
    • Occipital lobe - visual cortex
    • Temporal lobe - medial and inferolateral surfaces
  • Central branches
    • Thalamus
    • Subthalamus
    • Lentiform nucleus 
    • Midbrain 
    • Pineal gland
    • Superior and inferior colliculi
    • Medial and lateral geniculate bodies
  • Choroidal branches- choroid plexus of 
    • Lateral ventricle
    • Third ventricle 

The image given below shows the posterior cerebral arteries in the circle of Willis.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo, nystagmus, left-sided Horner's syndrome with numbness of left face and right limbs. What is the largest branch of the affected artery marked in the image as 'X'?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wallenberg's syndrome (lateral medullary syndrome) and the marked vessel is the vertebral artery. The largest branch of this artery is the posterior inferior cerebellar artery.

The vertebral artery is a branch of the first part of the subclavian artery. It enters the skull through the foramen magnum and terminates by joining the vertebral artery of the opposite side forming the basilar artery. The branches of the cranial portion of the vertebral artery are:

  • Meningeal branches - supplying dura of posterior cranial fossa
  • Posterior spinal arteries - supply posterior one-third of the spinal cord
  • Anterior spinal artery - supply anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery - supplies the lateral part of the medulla, cerebellar hemisphere, and the choroid plexus of the fourth ventricle. 
  • Medullary branches - supplying the medulla
 The image given below shows the vertebral artery.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body
  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Vertigo
  • Horner's syndrome
  • dysphagia
  • Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis
  • Loss of gag reflex

Weber's syndrome

Posterior cerebral artery
  • I/L Oculomotor nerve palsy - ptosis with fixed dilated pupil pointed down and out
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • C/L paralysis of the lower face

C/L- Contralateral

I/L-Ipsilateral

questions.text: Which of the following arteries do not supply the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is medulla oblongata. The superior cerebellar artery does not supply the medulla oblongata.

questions.text: The blood supply to the structure marked in the image is by:
questions.solution:
The marked structure is fornix which is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.

The anteromedial central branches from the anterior cerebral artery supply the fornix along with optic chiasma, lamina terminalis, hypothalamus, para-olfactory areas, and cingulate gyrus.

questions.text: A hypertensive man suffered a sudden right brachiofacial paresis with dysarthria. CT showed a haemorrhage in the left basal ganglia and angiography revealed a Charcot-Bouchard aneurysm. The affected artery is a branch of:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a Charcot-Bouchard aneurysm. The affected artery is the Charcot's artery which is the striate branch of the middle cerebral artery marked as 'C' in the above image. 

Charcot-Bouchard aneurysms are located in the lenticulostriate vessels of the basal ganglia and are commonly associated with hypertension. Charcot's artery supplies the internal capsule and basal ganglia. It is also known as the 'Charcot's artery of cerebral haemorrhage'. 

 

The image given below shows the circle of Willis at the base of the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the blood supply of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the posterior limb of the internal capsule and the recurrent artery of Heubner is not a part of its blood supply. 

The posterior limb of internal capsule is supplied by:
  • Charcot's artery (branch of middle cerebral artery)
  • Anterior choroidal artery (branch of internal carotid artery)
  • Posterolateral branches of posterior cerebral artery.

Related Pearl: Blood supply of internal capsule.

 
Blood supply of internal capsule.

Anterior limb 

  • Recurrent artery of Heubner
Genu 
  • Recurrent artery of Heubner
  • Charcot's artery (lenticulostriate artery or artery of cerebral hemorrrahge)
Posterior limb
  • Charcot's artery (branch of Middle cerebral artery)
  • Anterior choroidal artery ( branch of internal carotid artery)
  • Posterolateral branches of posterior cerebral artery
Sublentiform part
  • Anterior choroidal artery
  • Posterior cerebral artery
Retrolentiform part
  • Posterolateral branches of posterior cerebral artery

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the blood supply of putamen?
questions.solution:
Posterior communicating artery does not supply the putamen.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man had a severe head injury resulting in headaches, nausea, and vertigo. His CT scan is shown below. Where does the affected cerebral vein drain into?
questions.solution:
CT image showing a crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion, is suggestive of acute subdural hematoma. The head injury leads to a tear in the cerebral veins (predominantly the bridging veins like the superior cerebral vein) causing the hematoma. The superior cerebral vein drains into the superior sagittal sinus.

Veins of the cerebral hemispheres can be categorized into superficial and deep. The superficial veins chiefly drain the cerebral cortex, while the deep veins return blood from the deep structures of the cerebrum.

Superficial veins:

  1. Superior cerebral veins:
    These veins drain the upper parts of the superolateral and medial surfaces of the cerebral hemisphere. They drain blood into the superior sagittal sinus.
  2. Inferior cerebral veins:
    These veins return blood from the inferior aspect of the cerebral hemisphere into the transverse, superior petrosal, cavernous and sphenoparietal sinuses. Some also drain into the inferior sagittal sinus.
  3. Superficial middle cerebral vein:
    This vein receives blood from veins on the superolateral surface. It terminates in the cavernous sinus.

Deep veins:

  1. Internal cerebral veins:
    This pair of veins originates at the foramen of Munro and eventually anastomoses to form the great vein of Galen.
  2. Basal veins:
    The two basal veins are closely related to the midbrain structures and drain into the great vein of Galen. 
  3. Great cerebral vein:
    The two internal cerebral veins unite to form the great cerebral vein before it passes beneath the corpus callosum and anastomoses with the straight sinus.

questions.text: What structure receives drainage from the superficial middle cerebral vein?
questions.solution:
The superficial middle cerebral vein drains into the cavernous sinus.

Superficial middle cerebral vein lies in the lateral sulcus and drains most of the lateral surface of the hemispheres. It drains into the cavernous sinus.
Superficial middle cerebral vein is connected to the superior sagittal sinus through the superior anastomotic vein of Trolord and to the transverse sinus through the inferior anastomotic vein of Labbe.

questions.text: Two internal cerebral veins join to form:
questions.solution: Two internal cerebral veins join to form the great cerebral vein of Galen beneath the splenium of the corpus callosum. It receives the basal veins and drains into the straight sinus.

questions.text: Where does the great cerebral vein of Galen drain into?
questions.solution:
The great cerebral vein of Galen drains into the straight sinus.

The image given below shows the venous drainage of cerebral veins.
